title: Medieval Europe from Constantine to St Louis
Friedrich Heer, The Medieval World (London, 1963

container-title: is a riveting survey of medieval Christianity, and Colin Morris, The Papal Monarchy 1050–1250
note: a masterly account of change in the church.
title: My own view of the transformation of Europe between the eleventh and thirteenth centuries which framed the changes discussed in this book is set out in R
A History of Christianity
The standard English-language accounts of heresy in our period are Malcolm Lambert, Medieval Heresy
and Scholars in the High Middle Ages

container-title: My discussion of the burning at Reims follows Edward L. Peters, The Magician, the Witch and the Law
note: a pioneer of sophisticated (but very readable) source criticism. For a superb study of the European witch craze see Robin Briggs, Witches and Neighbours (London, 1996), and for the emergence of systematic persecution as a peculiarly European phenomenon R.
title: The motto at the head of the Prologue is from the opening
The Mythology of the Secret Societies

an exemplary study of the growth and influence of irrational belief in a widespread and sinister conspiracy. Another is Norman Cohn’s study of the origins of the European witch craze of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, Europe’s Inner Demons

which includes an important discussion of the demonisation of heretics in the thirteenth century and shows how the traditional acceptance of continuity between heresy and witch beliefs was largely based on forged documents
The Formation of a Persecuting Society

note: The Letters and Poems of Fulbert of Chartres are translated by Fredrick Behrends
title: For the politics of marriage, including the marriages of King Robert II, (Chapters 1, 2) see Georges Duby, The Knight, the Lady and the Priest
The Envy of Angels

container-title: W. Southern, Scholastic Humanism and the Unification of Europe

title: For the apostolic tradition and the movements inspired by it and the religious repercussions of social change (Chapters 3–8) see Herbert Grundmann’s immensely influential Religious Movements of the High Middle Ages (Notre Dame, 1995; from the 2nd German edn of 1961),Henrietta Leyser, Hermits and the New Monasticism
Religious Poverty and the Profit Economy in Medieval Europe

title: The Hidden History of Women’s Ordination

note: and Norman Cohn, Europe’s Inner Demons; on images of heretics, see Alessia Trivellone, L’hérétique imaginé (Turnholt, 2009) and Sarah Lipton, Images of Intolerance (Berkeley, CA, 1999); on Conrad of Marburg and Robert le Bougre, see Karen Sullivan, The Inner Lives of the Medieval Inquisitors (Chicago, IL, 2011); on the Great Alleluia, Augustine Thompson, Revival Preachers and Politics in Thirteenth-Century Italy (Oxford, 1992).
title: introductions to the Albigensian Crusade (Chapters 14, 15) and the only one to take full account of recent scholarship on heresy, although Jonathan Sumption, The Albigensian Crusade
Crusade and Inquisition in Southern France, 1100–1250
remain useful. For the background and influence of Vox in Rama (Chapter 17) see Peters, The Magician, the Witch and the Law

note: and Karen Sullivan, Inner Lives. The literature on the findings of the inquisitors in southern France (especially) and Italy is even larger and more diverse. Malcolm
title: Inquisition
is the best introduction to an enormous literature, and James Given, Inquisition and Medieval Society
to its daily working (Chapter 18); valuable recent additions that prefer new insights to routine denunciation are Christine Caldwell Ames, Righteous Persecution

note: Montaillou (Epilogue) is the subject of two fascinating and contrasting reconstructions: Emmanuel Leroy Ladurie, Montaillou: Cathars and Catholics in a French Village
title: The Cathars
and Malcolm Barber The Cathars: Dualist Heretics in Languedoc

are admirable statements of the traditional view, and Caterina Bruschi, The Wandering Heretics of the Languedoc (Cambridge, 2009) is rich in insight. All of them, however, are superseded in varying degrees by Mark Pegg’s brilliant The Corruption of Angels: The Great Inquisition of 1245–46
which offers a devastating critique of the methods of his predecessors and an entirely fresh understanding of the religion of the good men
The Yellow Cross
Stephen O’Shea, The Friar of Carcassonne
is a lively and revealing account of resistance to the excesses of the inquisitors. Karen Sullivan, Truth and the Heretic

shows how the heretic became the model of the secret traitor. Malcolm Barber’s fine study of The Trial of the Templars (Cambridge, 1978) laid many myths to rest. The same cannot be said for Umberto Eco’s novel The Name of the Rose
based on the pursuit of the Spiritual Franciscans, but it is a uniquely compelling evocation of the world whose genesis this book has tried to explain
